16845.body: Another solid contemporary book with a peculiar argument ... again Douglas Coupland gone to the dark side, sort of.

16846.body: A good story of the kind I like the most ... a personal story. Throw in a war and some libertine experiences and you have one of my favourite readings of all times.

16849.body: A great way of getting to know how Palahniuk writes his fiction by looking at how he observes the real real world.

16968.body: Carl Hiaasen is a Florida journalist with a wicked sense of humor and the funniest characters around. This is a great read about an overprotective mother who hatches a scheme to go after the telemarketer who interrupts her dinner hour with her son. A funny tale, fast read.

16971.body: Poignant, often times haunting, story about a little girl who disappears from a small town. It's told from the point of view of several characters and stays with you long after you put it down. The writing is amazingly luminous but the plot line is a little troublesome.

16972.body: I read this book to Klara every night. It's a nice tale about love and loss. A bunny and baby are friends; bunny disappears; and then reunion. She loves the close-ups of the baby's face.

16986.body: The book is a selection of short stories that are set up so that they r in chronological order. While most of the are "based on true events" the author hints, that the book "is still a work of fiction", I'm sure he used writers leverage to change things around quite a bit. 17053.body: Lou Gherig was an amazing man. A model citizen and hard worker. His death was a very unfair thing because he led a better life than most people ever have. The book is great and I'm not much of a non-fiction book reader myself but this was a good read.

17061.recommended_for: Any one who has read other Lord of the Rings/Hobbit books
